member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver
member.summary: A class to manage the EasyDriver v4.4. An Open Source Hardware Stepper Motor Drive Project.
member.remarks: Thanks to Gus (GHI Electronics team). You may have some additional information about this class on http://webge.github.io/EasyStepperDriver/

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.Mode
member.summary: Modes are Full, Half, Quarter, OneEighth

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.StepDelay
member.summary: Get or set time between two step

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.#ctor(Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the driver, that only lets you move and choose direction.
member.param: (DIR) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver up that way) digital signal. The level if this signal (high/low) is sampled on each rising edge of STEP to determine which direction to take the step (or microstep).
(STEP) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver that way) digital signal. Each rising edge of this signal will cause one step (or microstep) to be taken.

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.#ctor(Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the driver, that only lets you move, choose direction and put the controller to sleep.
member.param: (DIR) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver up that way) digital signal. The level if this signal (high/low) is sampled on each rising edge of STEP to determine which direction to take the step (or microstep).
(STEP) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver that way) digital signal. Each rising edge of this signal will cause one step (or microstep) to be taken.
(SLP) This normally high input signal will minimize power consumption by disabling internal circuitry and the output drivers when pulled low.(disabled by default)

members.member:
Creates an instance of the driver, that only lets you move, choose direction and select step mode.
(DIR) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver up that way) digital signal. The level if this signal (high/low) is sampled on each rising edge of STEP to determine which direction to take the step (or microstep). (STEP) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver that way) digital signal. Each rising edge of this signal will cause one step (or microstep) to be taken. /// (MS1) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default) (MS2) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.#ctor(Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the driver, that only lets you move, choose direction, sleep, and select step mode.
member.param: (DIR) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver up that way) digital signal. The level if this signal (high/low) is sampled on each rising edge of STEP to determine which direction to take the step (or microstep).
(STEP) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver that way) digital signal. Each rising edge of this signal will cause one step (or microstep) to be taken.
(MS1) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default)
(MS2) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default)
(SLP) This normally high input signal will minimize power consumption by disabling internal circuitry and the output drivers when pulled low.(disabled by default)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.EasyStepperDriver.#ctor(Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin,Microsoft.SPOT.Hardware.Cpu.Pin)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the driver, that only lets you move, choose direction, sleep, select step mode and enable / disable card
member.param: (DIR) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver up that way) digital signal. The level if this signal (high/low) is sampled on each rising edge of STEP to determine which direction to take the step (or microstep).
(STEP) This needs to be a 0V to 5V (or 0V to 3.3V if you've set your Easy Driver that way) digital signal. Each rising edge of this signal will cause one step (or microstep) to be taken.
(MS1) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default)
(MS2) These digital inputs control the microstepping mode. Possible settings are (MS1/MS2) : full step (0,0), half step (1,0), 1/4 step (0,1), and 1/8 step (1,1 : default)
(SLP) This normally high input signal will minimize power consumption by disabling internal circuitry and the output drivers when pulled low.(disabled by default)
(EN) This normally low input signal will disable all outputs when pulled high.

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x
member.summary: MotorControlMD2x Dual 12Volt 2.8Amp H Bridge Motor Drive class
member.remarks: You may have some additional information about this class on https://github.com/WebGE/MD25

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x._transactionTimeOut
member.summary: Transaction time out = 1s before throwing System.IO.IOException

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister.Mode0
member.summary: (Default Setting) - The speed registers is literal speeds in the range of (see below)
member.remarks: Speed registers : 0 (Full Reverse) 128 (Stop) 255 (Full Forward)

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister.Mode1
member.summary: Mode 1 is similar to Mode 0, except that the speed values are interpreted as signed values.
member.remarks: Speed registers : -128 (Full Reverse) 0 (Stop) 127 (Full Forward).

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister.Mode2
member.summary: Speed1 control both motors speed, and speed2 becomes the turn value.
member.remarks: Data is in the range of 0 (Full Reverse) 128 (Stop) 255 (Full Forward)

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister.Mode3
member.summary: Mode 3 is similar to Mode 2, except that the speed values are interpreted as signed values.
member.remarks: Data is in the range of -128 (Full Reverse) 0 (Stop) 127 (Full Forward)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.#ctor
member.summary: This constructor assumes the default factory Slave Address = 0x58 and default bus frequency = 100Khz

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.#ctor(System.UInt16)
member.summary: This constructor allows user to specify the Slave Address (bus frequency = 100Khz)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.#ctor(System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary: This constructor allows user to specify the Slave Address and the bus frequency

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.Battery
member.summary: Return as 10 times the voltage (121 for 12.1V)

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.AccelerationRate
member.summary: Set or return optional acceleration register (1, 2, 3, 5(default), 10). See datasheet to calculate the time (in seconds) for the acceleration to complete.
member.remarks: If you require a controlled acceleration period for the attached motors to reach there ultimate speed, the MD25 has the ability to provide this. It works by using a sent acceleration value and incrementing the power by that value.

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.Mode
member.summary: Return the mode of operation among Mode0, Mode1, Mode2 or Mode3

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.Command
member.summary: Set or return the command register value.
member.remarks: 0x20(32) Resets the encoder registers to zero. 0x30(48) Disables automatic speed regulation. 0x31(49) Enables automatic speed regulation (default). 0x32(50) Disables 2 second timeout of motors (Version 2 onwards only). 0x33(51) Enables 2 second timeout of motors when no I2C comms (default) (Version 2 onwards only) See datasheet for more informations (changing the I2C Bus Address).

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.TransactionTimeOut
member.summary: Set or return time before System IO Exception if transaction failed (in ms).
member.remarks: 1000ms by default

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.GetAllRegisters
member.summary: Read all registers and calculate Encoder1 and Encoder2 value.

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.SetMode(Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister)
member.summary: The mode register selects which mode of operation and I2C data input type the user requires.
member.param: Mode0, Mode1, Mode2 or Mode3 (see MotorControlMD2x.ModeRegister)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.RazEncoders
member.summary: Set encoder registers value (Enc1a,b,c,d and Enc2a,b,c,d) to 0.

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.MotorDrivers.MotorControlMD2x.SetSpeedTurn(System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Adjusts the speed of the motors in mode 0 and 1. Speed and Turn in mode 2 and 3
member.remarks: Turn mode looks at the speed register to decide if the direction is forward or reverse. Then it applies a subtraction or addition of the turn value on either motor. If the direction is forward motor speed1 = speed - turn, motor speed2 = speed + turn else the direction is reverse so motor speed1 = speed + turn, motor speed2 = speed - turn
member.param: Speed motor2 value (mode0 and 1). Turn value (mode 2 and 3)

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x
member.summary: A Class to manage the MicroChip MCP342x, 18-Bit Multi-Channel delta-sigma ADC series with I²C Interface and On-Board Reference
member.remarks: Can be used with MCP3422/3/4.

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.SampleRate
member.summary: Resolution Selection affects convertion time (more bits, slower conversion)

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.ConversionMode
member.summary: Use One-Shot if very low power consuption is required

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.ConversionMode.OneShot
member.summary: The device performs a single conversion and enters a low current standby mode automatically until it receives another conversion command. This reduces current consumption greatly during idle periods.

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.ConversionMode.Continuous
member.summary: The conversion takes place continuously at the set conversion speed. See Resolution. (By default on power-up)

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.Channel
member.summary: MCP3422 and MCP3423 devices have two differential input channels and the MCP3424 has four differential input channels

member.name: T:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.PGA_Gain
member.summary: Selects the gain factor for the input signal before the analog-to-digital conversion takes place

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.PGA_Gain.x1
member.summary: By default on power-up Gain = x1

member.name: F:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x._config
member.summary: MCP342x configuration : SLave Address and Frequency

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.#ctor(System.UInt16,System.Int16)
member.summary: Basic Constructor - By default on power-up (Channel = CH1, Resolution = 12-bit, Conversion = Continuous, Gain = 1)
member.param: 7 bits Slave Address 0x68, 0x6A, 0x6C or 0x6E (0x68 by default)
Standard : 100kHz to fast 400kHz or high-speed (3.4MHz) (100kHz by default)

member.name: M:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.ConfigDevice(System.Byte)
member.param: RDY C1 C0 /O_C S1 S0 G1 G0 = 00010000 (default)

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.Resolution
member.summary: Get or Set Sample Rate Selection Bit
member.remarks: Get : 0 => 240 SPS (12 bits) (Default), 1 => 60 SPS (14 bits), 2 => 15 SPS (16 bits), 3 => 3.75 SPS (18 bits)

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.Gain
member.summary: Get or Set PGA Gain Selection Bits

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.CHannel
member.summary: Get or Set Channel Selection Bits
member.remarks: MCP3422 and MCP3423 : CH1 or CH2 - MCP3424 : CH1, CH2, CH3 or CH4

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.Mode
member.remarks: One-Shot Conversion mode or Continuous Conversion mode

member.name: P:Microtoolskit.Hardware.IO.MCP342x.TransactionTimeOut
member.summary: Time before System IO Exception if transaction failed
member.remarks: 1000ms by default

member.summary: Reads the selected input channel and converts to voltage units

member.summary: Reads the raw counts from the ADC
